content: I see no problem with imaging both sides of our borders for security purposes or monitoring drug trafficking or illegal immigration for that matter. Citizens that are opposed to be seen by a sat must have something to hide (criminal activity?)

content: well, that was the thought behind the wire tapping too, that if you have nothing to hide why would you care if it can save lives. but many think the government will become big brother if we start there, like they are not already? pffffft so, they can listen to phone calls, see us on sat at all times and probably can even read our email. but they can't find Bin Laden?? Who is the criminal here?

content: quote: Originally posted by excgcdr: I see no problem with imaging both sides of our borders for security purposes or monitoring drug trafficking or illegal immigration for that matter. Citizens that are opposed to be seen by a sat must have something to hide (criminal activity?) How would you accomplish that? I would love to see how you would put an imaging satellites in orbit so they would have constant coverage of the entire US border. Also how many people would you have to have analyzing the images to actually find illegal immigrants or illegal activity. Also what would the point be since data is certain to be old by the time it has been taken and actually looked at to figure out what is in the pictures. I am sure it would be okay, since anybody that objects has to be a criminal. Nevermind the 4th Amendment it can't be that important, after all it is just the Constitution.
